awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Study of A- and B-class dye-decolorizing peroxidases (DyPs): From molecular mechanisms to applications in dye removal and lignin degradation
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Ping Li from Kansas State University and Dr. Likai Song from Florida State University to investigate the molecular mechanism of A- and B-class dye-decolorizing peroxidases (DyPs) and their structure-property-reactivity-function (SPRF) relationship. The results of this investigation can be used in the development of biocatalysts for wastewater treatment and biofuel production. The proposed studies fill the critical knowledge gap regarding DyPs and guide protein engineering that could lead to enzymes with enhanced oxidative activity. This pursuit allows the graduate students and postdoctoral trainees to acquire expertise in multidisciplinary areas spanning from Chemistry to Biology, thus preparing them to become successful next-generation scientists. Contributions are also made to an outreach program that encourages students from groups underrepresented in STEM careers to major in science.      
 
This research project seeks to elucidate the molecular mechanism and SPRF relationship of DyPs, a new family of H2O2-dependent heme peroxidases. The studies focus on TcDyP from Thermomonospora curvata and ElDyP from Enterobacter lignolyticus as the representatives for the A- and B-class enzymes from this family, respectively. The residues situated on the enzyme surface that are responsible for substrate oxidation in TcDyP, the residue(s) that control one- and two-electron reduction reactions that involve ElDyP compound I, and the dynamics of the loop surrounding the heme pocket in DyPs are being studied using structural biology, enzymology, and electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) investigation methods. Organic synthesis and protein engineering are being utilized to define and modulate the SPRF relationship. Information from this study not only fills the fundamental knowledge gap on DyPs but also paves the way for DyPs' applications in dye removal and lignin degradation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Dye-decolorizing peroxidases (DyPs) are a new family of heme peroxidases that are poorly understood, but have a promising future in industrial dye removal and lignin degradation. Synthetic dyes are pollutants that cause deterioration of water systems and represent health threats to human beings. Lignin is the most abundant renewable carbon source on Earth, and its breakdown is a limiting factor for biofuel production and lignin valorization. DyPs use H2O2 as an electron acceptor to catalyze a number of oxidative reactions. The molecular mechanisms and structure-property-reactivity-function relationships of the DyPs remain unexplored, which has severely hindered the development of DyP applications. To fill this critical knowledge gap, this research aimed to characterize A- and B-class DyPs using electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) along with other structural biology and enzymology techniques. Specifically, we used the B-class ElDyP from Enterobacter lignolyticus as a model system to understand radical generation in the presence of H2O2. We studied the wild-type and D143H mutant of EIDyP. The latter was constructed to mimic classical class II plant peroxidases, which include many other lignin-degrading enzymes. Radical formation in the presence of H2O2 was performed under various pH conditions and reaction times and characterized using EPR spectroscopy. The results suggest that formation of protein radicals by ElDyP is efficient. In addition, radical formation is pH dependent, and D143 is important for the reaction. The time-dependent EPR data were consistent with the results of the transient kinetic study of ElDyP, in which the radical formation rate of the wild-type protein was much faster than that of the D143H mutant. Further efforts to enhance its lignolytic activity should focus on the control of radical propagation to protein surface. We also compared the radical formation between ElDyP and another B-class DyPB from Rhodococcus jostii RHA1. Our results indicate that the D153A mutant in DyPB and the D143A mutant in EIDyP impair radical formation. However, the two residues might have different roles in regulating reaction kinetics. This study provides insight into the molecular mechanisms of the DyPs and could potentially benefit society through promoting the adoption of renewable resources (e.g., biomass feedstock) and greener chemical processes (e.g., enzymatic oxidation).

 


Last Modified: 11/27/2021
Modified by: Likai Song
